Office Address:   13 University Place, 627  New York, New York (US) 10003   Email:     ludovic.cortade@nyu.edu     Phone:   (212) 992-7993   Fax:   (212) 995-4187       Bio   In my research, I analyze how films both constitute a symbol of modernity and present us with resurgences of collective beliefs that pre-existed the invention of the cinema. I investigate how mass audiences embrace films on the basis of myths and sensibilities that may revive or adjust ancient narratives to modern times. Literature, aesthetics, history, geography and sociology are key in my attempt to excavate these resurgences. I have written on the relationships between film and literature, theory, space, and politics. My current research focuses on how French film theorists and critics laid the foundation for a sociological approach to film prior to the advent of political modernism. Conducted in ENGLISH No knowledge of French  required.               Cross-listed  with the department of Cinema Studies (Tisch School of the Arts) and the  Dramatic Literature Department       Goals of the course :                 Students will :       - learn about the history  of French cinema from its origin to the present day;              - become familiar with varied  aspects of French civilization (history, literature, class, gender, ethnicity,  etc.);       - gain the ability to discuss and analyse  landmark French films through the lens of style and culture;              - learn to write a comprehensive scene analysis using the  methodology of Cinema Studies.       - discuss the concept of  “Frenchness” and examine the many cross-cultural interactions between French cinema the cinema of foreign countries.          The following periods will be  discussed: Early cinema (the Lumière brothers vs. Méliès); Surrealism and the  international Avant-Garde of the 1920s, Poetic Realism and the Golden Age of  French classical cinema (Vigo, Carné, Renoir), the “New Wave” (Truffaut,  Godard, Resnais, etc.), Political Modernism and the events of May 1968, the  “Cinéma du Look” (Besson, Beineix), Heritage Cinema and the challenges of  globalization.          Book (required) :      Alan WILLIAMS:  Republic  of Images : A History of French Filmmaking . Cambridge : Harvard  University Press, 1992.          Evaluation :       Midterm Test :  20%      Clip analysis  #1 : 20 %      Clip analysis #  2 : 20 %      Final Exam: 20  %      Attendance and  reading: 20 %            Films to be shown and discussed:             - Selection of films by the Lumière brothers and Georges Méliès  (1895-1902)      Two conceptions of cinema : reality  captured through the lens of the Lumière brothers and the bold special effects  of Méliès, the « Cinemagician ».          - The Age  of Gold (1930) by Luis Buñuel      At the forefront of cinematic Surrealism , The  Age of Gold is the most blasphemous and anti-bourgeois of all Buñuel’s  films. A ban was placed on the film for 50 years…          - L’Atalante   (1934) by Jean Vigo      « Classical, almost violent and always  tormented, fevered, overflowing with ideas and with fantasy » (Elie  Faure). The film made by a 27 year old director exerted a far reaching  influence on world cinema, including on « New Wave » director  François Truffaut.          - Day  Break (1939) by Marcel Carné      One of the best examples of the film movement  known as poetic realism , Day Break   epitomizes the Golden Age of classical cinema and the desillusions of class  struggle a few months before the outbreak of WWII.          - The  Rules of the Games (1939) by Jean Renoir      The film was initially condemned for its  description of the French upper classes. The French government banned it, but  after the War it has come to be seen by many film critics and directors as one  of the greatest films of all time.          - My  Uncle (1958) by Jacques Tati      A satire of postwar France's infatuation with  modern architecture, mechanical efficiency and American-style consumerism  (special Prize at the 1958 Cannes Film Festival ; 1959 Academy Award for  Best Foreign Film).           - Hiroshima  My Love (1959) by Alain Resnais      A film about the impossible relationship between  a French woman and a Japanese man questioning, love, war and memory. A film  made by one of the most influential French modernist director. Screenplay by  Marguerite Duras (Special Award at the 1959 Cannes Film Festival).          - Breathless (1960) by Jean-Luc Godard      A penniless young thug who models himself on the  film persona of Humphrey Bogart… On the run from the police, he turns to his  American girlfriend, a student and aspiring journalist, who sells the New York  Herald Tribune on the streets of Paris... A film that symbolizes the « New  Wave » for its bold visual style (1960 Jean Vigo Prize).          -  Tout va bien (1972) by Jean-Luc Godard and  Jean-Pierre Gorin      How can cinema have a real impact on society ? Godard  and Gorin explore the intersections of radicalism with cinema and modernism in  the wake of the May 68’ riots.          -  Diva (1981) by Jean-Jacques Beineix      The story of a young postal carrier with a  passion for music. A film whose camera movements,  soundtrack, stylishness and… blue lighting testify to the crisis of political  modernism in France in the 1980s.          - Hate (1995) by  Mathieu Kassovitz      The story of three young friends in an  impoverished multi-ethnic housing project in the aftermath of a great riot  (Best Director Award for 28 years old Kassovitz at the Cannes Film Festival).          - A Self Made Hero   (1996) by Jacques Audiard      How an ordinary young man reinvents himself  during after the liberation of France by storing and memorizing data to become  a hero of the French Resistance. (De)constructing collective memory through  film... Goal  of the course :       The relationships  between French cinema and politics are twofold : cinema is not only the  mirror image of the political situation in France. It has also been seen as a  key factor in political change. The goal of the course is to analyze the  representation of the political backdrop in French cinema and the shaping of a  collective political consciousness through film in France from the 1930s to the  election of Nicolas Sarkozy. The emphasis is placed on film analysis, the  review of the historical context and the theoritical debates gravitating around  film form and ideology.           The following periods and themes will be discussed :            - The social struggles of the 1930s : the cinema of the  Popular Front ;      - The cinema of Occupation and the impact of the Vichy  ideology on filmmaking (1940-44) ;      - The Cold War, decolonization, filmmaking and film  criticism in the 1950s;      - May 1968, Political modernism and the diverging paths of  the New Wave ;      - Post-modernism and the dusk of the « cinéma  engagé » in the 1980s;      - The revival of politics in the 1990s – 2000s: social  struggle and national identity in the context of globalization.
